Code: B420
Credential: Ontario College Graduate Certificate

context:
Program Name: Sport and Event Marketing
Code: B420

Method of Study: Full-time

Location: Online
Program Description: The Sport and Event Marketing graduate certificate program provides students with the knowledge and skills employers seek in sports, arts and entertainment and not-for-profit marketing careers. The program is part of George Brown's online postgraduate programs offering flexibility for working professionals.
Note: This program is also offered full-time in person. For more information, see Sport and Event Marketing postgraduate program (B400).

The Sport and Event Marketing program covers marketing in the sectors of sports, arts, entertainment, sponsorship activation, event planning, integrated marketing communications (IMC), digital marketing, non-profit marketing, and financial metrics. Students have the opportunity to involve industry partners, particularly during the final semester when planning and running a charitable event.

The program offers extracurricular opportunities like speed mentoring and attending Canada’s Sports Business Awards (5 to Watch). Students will be able to show off skills such as creating integrated marketing plans, organizing events, developing sponsorship opportunities, and creating professional presentations using industry-standard software.

This program is offered full-time in person and students wishing to apply should apply to B400. The program is part of the School of Marketing.

Technical requirements include a computer running on Windows 10 or Mac OSX, high-speed broadband access, headphones/speaker and microphone, a webcam, and a web browser. Mobile devices may allow for limited participation but cannot guarantee meeting all coursework needs.

The program requires the successful completion of one semester of work experience to graduate. This can be co-op (paid) or internship (unpaid). The work term occurs after the second academic semester, and students apply for opportunities through partnerships with employers and industry partners, undergoing a competitive interview process.

Students at George Brown College have the opportunity to gain work experience through competitive interviews for opportunities provided by the college, as well as pursuing self-directed industry experiences. The work experience can be added to students' resumes. The college offers field education opportunities with real-world challenges and clients at the Centre for Business.

George Brown Marketing students have access to membership in two Canadian marketing associations, the CMA and IAB, included in their tuition fees. CMA membership includes live and online events, professional development opportunities, tools, resources, and guides for members only, networking opportunities with thousands of marketers, and exclusive access to CMA NXT. IAB membership includes student volunteer opportunities for marquee events, members-only webinars and podcasts, original Canadian digital marketing research, globally accepted digital ad standards, and globally standardized courses, certification, and custom workshops.

Graduates of George Brown's Marketing program can find careers in industries such as amateur and professional sport, e-sports, arts and entertainment, consumer products, retail, tourism, hospitality, financial services, technology, special events, not for profit, business consulting, advertising, sponsorship, digital and experiential marketing. Potential positions include Account Manager/Executive, Event Coordinator, Game Operations Co-ordinator, Marketing Co-ordinator, Partnerships and Sponsorships Co-ordinator, and Ticket Sales Co-ordinator.

Industry feedback from Dan MacKenzie, who has hosted George Brown Sport and Event Marketing interns, states that these students have a built-in industry network when they arrive due to their classmates being spread throughout the industry, and many have had other work experiences which makes for a more mature and effective internship for the hosting organization.

The George Brown Sport and Event Marketing program is a domestic online program that requires students to complete 13 mandatory courses and 1 work experience term in order to graduate. The work experience term can be in the form of co-op, internship, simulation, consulting, or research projects. Some companies that have previously hired graduates from this program include the NBA Canada and Scotiabank, where they have provided valuable support for sponsorship programs and become important members of their marketing teams. The work experience term is typically taken in semester 4 (SEMESTER 2) and the code for this course is COOP 4001 / INTN 4001 / BAWT 4001.

Quotes from industry professionals:
- Dan MacKenzie, vice-president and managing director of NBA Canada (Graduate 1997), stated that the insights students gained from the George Brown Sport and Event Marketing program have made for a more mature, effective internship for the hosting organization.
- Matthew Coorsh, director of Marketing Sponsorships & Brand Management at Scotiabank, mentioned that the experience students gained from the program has allowed them to become important and trusted members of their marketing team.

The work experience term is typically taken in semester 4 (SEMESTER 2) and the code for this course is COOP 4001 / INTN 4001 / BAWT 4001.

- Dan MacKenzie, vice-president and managing director of NBA Canada (Graduate 1997), stated that the insights students gained from the George Brown Sport and Event Marketing program have made for a more mature, effective internship for the hosting organization.
- Matthew Coorsh, director of Marketing Sponsorships & Brand Management at Scotiabank, mentioned that the experience students gained from the program has allowed them to become important and trusted members of their marketing team.

The George Brown Sport and Event Marketing program is a domestic online program that requires students to complete 13 mandatory courses and 1 work experience term in order to graduate. The graduate of this program is capable of applying marketing concepts to industries related to sports, arts, entertainment, or causes. They can develop integrated marketing and media plans with consumer-oriented objectives, strategies, tactics, budgetary considerations, and ROI metrics. Furthermore, they can plan, execute, and evaluate comprehensive events using project management and team building skills. The graduate is also able to develop and evaluate sponsorship activation opportunities from a consumer, property, and buyer perspective. They possess the skill to create professional written, digital, and other presentation formats using industry standard software. Additionally, they can analyze and interpret marketing activities based on sales forecasting, budgeting, financial health, and performance metrics.

The estimated tuition fee for this program is $4,112.00 for domestic students for the first two semesters starting in Fall 2023. However, it does not include the cost of books or the work experience semester fee. The additional fee for each work experience semester is $500.

This program is approved for OSAP funding, provided the applicant meets OSAP eligibility criteria. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. Prospective students with international transcripts who do not provide English proficiency test results must take the college level George Brown College English assessment to be considered for admission. Those considered based on work experience will also be required to provide proof of English proficiency and may need to write the George Brown College English admission assessment. Some college and university credits may qualify for exemptions, and applicants can check the transfer guide for more information.

The text does not contain any specific dates or names, nor any contact details for further information.

The text provides information on how to contact George Brown College for various inquiries. Here are the key contacts and resources mentioned:

1. Information Sessions: Sign up for an upcoming on-campus session or contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions section for domestic students' inquiries. International students should contact one of the international recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry through the International Contact Us page.
2. Domestic Student Admissions: Contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions section for details on admission requirements, deadlines, and the process.
3. Financial Aid: Contact the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid section for inquiries about OSAP, bursaries, scholarships, and other financial matters.
4. Entry Advising: Make an appointment to see an Entry Advisor for advice on program options and which program might be best suited for you. Review the frequently asked questions beforehand.
5. Centre for Business: For general inquiries, contact the Centre for Business at business@georgebrown.ca or phone (416) 415-5000 ext. 2160. For course-specific inquiries related to Sport & Event Marketing (B420), contact Peter Widdis (pwiddis@georgebrown.ca) or John Peco (john.peco@georgebrown.ca).
6. Virtual tour and Campus tour: You can take a virtual tour of the campus or book a physical campus tour.
7. Social Channels: Follow the Centre for Business on Instagram and LinkedIn.
8. Sign up to receive tailored resources to make your application process easier.

No specific program information was mentioned in the text.
